subNodes.conversationText: root
"What do you want? I thought we were through."
"You said I could eat and rest --"
"Yes, at seven, at the end of the day. It is not the end of the day; indeed, it is morning, and you were just here. Shoo."
"Apologies," said <FirstName>.
"I had questions for you."

"I have told you all you need to know for now. I'm busy." 

Eldest Lady did not look very busy. She was straightening bottles on a shelf, and she had only started straightening them when she said she was busy. But the young witch thought better of persisting.
"Apologies," said <FirstName>.
"Apologies," said <FirstName>.
The witches wondered why <FirstName> had returned before dinner.
"A spirit of the woods told me something interesting."
The witches looked intently at <FirstName>.
"I found the hunter and slew him, as you asked. Here's his blood."
"Let's see it," said Eldest Lady.
<FirstName> took out the blood and gave it to the witch.
"It is red."
[Continue.]
Eldest Lady uncorked it and passed it under her nose, grimacing. "Human, too."
"Did you think I would try to trick you?"
"No. You're not simple enough to try such tricks. Good <boy/girl>."
[Continue.]
"I'm pleased. Come, come. Let us go out back and see what the blood has to say."
[Continue.]

They went out to the backyard to Nnenne's grave. Eldest Lady and Middle One stood on either side of the mound, and <FirstName> stood at Nnenne's feet with Knott behind <him/her>. Pharaoh flew up to a low-hanging tree limb and watched the proceedings solemnly.
[Continue.]

"Tell us, blood, what we would know
Drip upon the ground below
Steam and smoke as it were snow
In the tendrils something show."
[Continue.]

"Entrail, entrail! Bone and blood!
Down we pour you in the mud!"
[Continue.]
"Did the flesh that held you slay her?"
[Continue.]
"Did the heart you filled betray her?"
[Continue.]
Eldest Lady let only one drop fall. It began to steam when it hit the ground. The steam thickened into ribbons that twisted into a vague, phantasmal face.
[Continue.]
"This hunter killed no one," it said. A light summer breeze leapt up, and the steam vanished. The blood stopped boiling and seeped into the soil.
[Continue.]
"You heard what it said. You took the wrong blood."
[Continue.]
"The right blood from the wrong hunter, sister."
"But his arrow matched the one you gave me."
"Go to, go to. A matchbox has many matches."
[Continue.]
"I see. I will draw the right blood from the right hunter next time."
"See that you do."
[Continue.]
"Well, well. You judge ill but can follow directions. That doesn't say much about you as a witch, but it does suggest you'd make a tolerable housemate."
[Continue.]
"She hates me," whispered Middle One in <FirstName>'s ear. "She likes you better."
[Continue.]
"What are you whispering to <him/her>?"
[Continue.]
"<He/She> asked what time it was."
[Continue.]

"The time? The time is too few minutes to our coven-binding. Take this," said Eldest Lady. "A poor trade for a man's life, but perhaps it will help you finish this task quickly."

Eldest Lady drew out a dagger whose touch was as cold as winter. "Cold blade, cold task," she said. "The murderer is still out there. Find them."
[Continue.]
Eldest Lady went back indoors. Middle One gave <FirstName> a rueful look before following her.
[End.]
[Continue.]
[Continue.]
[Continue.]
[Continue.]
[Continue.]
"How? I saw! I had a vision -- and --."
"There there," said Eldest Lady without a trace of sympathy. "A witch should never the trust the visions <he/she> gives <him/her>self."
[Continue.]
"I knew it, somehow... I felt that he was innocent. Why didn't I hold back?"
"There there," said Eldest Lady without a trace of sympathy.
[Continue.]
"That's unfortunate, but no great loss I think."
"You're in no position to judge."
[Continue.]
<FirstName> waited.
"I'm pleased. Come, come. Let us go out back and see what the blood has to say."
"I have more blood."
"Do you indeed? And is it guilty blood this time?"
"It is."
Once again, the three witches went into the backyard and stood around Nnenne's grave.
[Continue.]

"To tongueless blood we offer speech
So bloody lessons it might teach."
[Continue.]

"To dead man's blood we give new life
So it may talk despite the knife."
[Continue.]

"Entrail, entrail! Bone and blood!
Down we pour you in the mud!"
[Continue.]
"Did you pump through killer's veins?"
[Continue.]
"Did your own breath death sustain?"
[Continue.]
Once again, a phantasmal face formed after Eldest Lady let fall a drop of blood.
[Continue.]
Once again, the answer to the witches' question was no.
[Continue.]
"No. He killed no one," the face said. Then the steam blew away.
[Continue.]
Middle One and Eldest Lady exchanged glances.
"I've disappointed you."
"Yes. You have made a habit of it," she said, tucking the flask of blood into her robes.
[Continue.]
"Eldest Lady's a nun, and you're her tailor. But don't take it too hard, don't cry! Middle One will give you something for those tears."
[Continue.]
The young witch's eyes were dry, but Middle One nevertheless handed <him/her> a handkerchief.
[Continue.]
"One hunter remains. Bring us their blood. Do it soon."
[Continue.]
The two older witches went back inside.
[End.]
[Continue.]
[Continue.]
[Continue.]
[Continue.]
[Continue.]
"I've taken the life of another innocent."
"More importantly, you've taken blood that won't work in our coven-binding," she said, tucking the flask of blood into her robes.
[Continue.]
"Don't cry! Middle One will give you something for those tears."
[Continue.]
"I had reason to think I was doing the right thing."
"You were doing the right thing," said Middle One. "The right thing to the wrong person."
[Continue.]
"More importantly, you've taken blood that won't work in our coven-binding," she said, tucking the flask of blood into her robes.
"I believe it is."
Once again, the three witches went into the backyard and stood around Nnenne's grave.
"Let's find out."
Once again, the three witches went into the backyard and stood around Nnenne's grave.
"I talked to another spirit."
Eldest Lady sighed. "I've already told you: stay away from them. They will distract you, as they did him."
"In the vision they gave me, you tricked him into going to them."
"Malkin did what he liked. I did not trick him. He thought he could learn nothing more from us. I told him only the spirits could teach him more. Was that a trick? It was true. He knew the danger."
[Continue.]
Middle One only looked out the window sadly.
[Continue.]
"He was lucky. He didn't perish. And he is wiser than he was."
"Why haven't you told me exactly what's become of him?"

"Why haven't the spirits?" asked Eldest Lady. "Because they have something to hide. They would drag you along through mystery and doubt because that's their way. I want to tell you; indeed, it would be a good lesson for you. But I can't. We have sworn ourselves to silence on this matter. Pry no further. It will do you no good."
[Continue.]
Middle One began sweeping crumbs of bread from the table.
"Allow me to ask just one more question. What was in the grimoire he took?"

"This grimoire?" asked Eldest Lady. She took the book <FirstName> had seen in <his/her> vision from on top of a shelf. Its pages crinkled as she opened it. She ran her hand along one of the pages lovingly.
The young witch didn't relent. "In the vision the spirits gave me, you used the book to trick Malkin."
"Malkin did what he liked. I did not trick him. He thought he could learn nothing more from us. I told him only the spirits could teach him more. Was that a trick? It was true. He knew the danger."
<FirstName> asked no more questions.
<FirstName> asked no more questions.
<FirstName> asked no more questions.
<FirstName> asked no more questions.
<FirstName> asked no more questions.
<FirstName> asked no more questions.
"What was in the grimoire he took?"
<FirstName> asked no more questions.
<FirstName> asked no more questions.
<FirstName> asked no more questions.
<FirstName> asked no more questions.
<FirstName> asked no more questions.
<FirstName> asked no more questions.
"What was in the grimoire he took?"

"This grimoire?" asked Eldest Lady. She took the book <FirstName> had seen in <his/her> vision from on top of a shelf. Its pages crinkled as she opened it. She ran her hand along one of the pages lovingly.
"Yes, that's it."
Eldest Lady closed the book.
"Yes. Can I see it?"
Eldest Lady laughed. "No! Not yet. Once you are in the coven, maybe. Certainly not now." She closed the book.
[Continue.]

"It contains many things. Spells of my youth, spells of my old age. Spells that Middle One and I made together, and others from covens long ago. Lore known by none but myself -- most of it trivial, I'll admit, but precious in its way -- and other lore that could shake kingdoms. And, yes, things I've learned from the kami, wisdom they gave me that I only half-understand. Dangerous writing."
[Continue.]
She put the book back.
"In the vision the spirits gave me, you used the book to trick Malkin."
"Malkin did what he liked. I did not trick him. He thought he could learn nothing more from us. I told him only the spirits could teach him more. Was that a trick? It was true. He knew the danger."
"Why haven't you told me exactly what's become of Malkin?"

"Why haven't the spirits?" asked Eldest Lady. "Because they have something to hide. They would drag you along through mystery and doubt because that's their way. I want to tell you; indeed, it would be a good lesson for you. But I can't. We have sworn ourselves to silence on this matter. Pry no further. It will do you no good."
<FirstName> asked no more questions.
<FirstName> asked no more questions.

Afterwards, Middle One showed the young witch to <his/her> bed. It was a hard, narrow thing with a thin blanket of wool on top of it, a wooden pillow, and a threadbare gray sheet. It sat beneath an open window that looked south into the woods.
<FirstName> asked no more questions.
The events of the last two days had taxed the young witch, and <he/she> fell asleep on the hard, small bed as if it had light sheets and soft cushions.
<FirstName> asked no more questions.
Though the night was almost as warm as the day had been, the song of the crickets and a light breeze that blew through the window put the young witch to sleep within minutes.
<FirstName> asked no more questions.
The young witch could not get to sleep for some time that night, maybe because of the unusually rich supper <he/she>'d had -- and as soon as <he/she> did, a thunderstorm woke <him/her> up.
<FirstName> asked no more questions.

It was August, but the day had been mild and breezy. When night fell, it became almost cold. When the young witch woke the next morning, <he/she> was surprised to find Middle One's white fawn pressed up against <his/her> legs. As soon as <he/she> stirred, the creature darted off.
<FirstName> said nothing.
Eldest Lady closed the book.
[Continue.]
"Why haven't you told me exactly what's become of him?"
"I know what happened to Malkin. You tricked him, and the kami transformed him into a tree," said <FirstName> suddenly.
"I went to the Roots of the World. The Congress of Moths showed me what happened to Nnenne."
"You visited the Roots of the World?"
The young witch didn't have any reason to disturb them.
"The goose-fletched arrows," said <FirstName>. "I found out a boy makes them."
"The woodcutter's son? I thought so," said Eldest Lady. "He's a very peculiar boy. Stay away from him."
"A witch being warned away from a boy? That's a reversal."
"Not everything in these woods is as it appears."
[Continue.]
"Not even you, sister?!" said Middle One in mock-amazement.
[Continue.]
"No. Not even me."
"What I'm saying," said the young witch, exasperated, "is that this arrow can't help me."
"You told me to look for the hunter who shoots with arrows like this. But all three of them use arrows like this."
"He told me that he fletches these arrows for the hunters."
"There's nothing surprising about that. They have to get them somewhere."
[Continue.]

"Where do the dragons get their teeth?
From bones, from bones."
"What I'm saying," said the young witch, exasperated, "is that this arrow can't help me."

"I may have overstated the arrow's conclusiveness. But it is still useful. You know that Nnenne's killer is one of the three who shoots with such arrows. Better to know that the killer is one of three than it is to guess that he's one of three thousand."
[Continue.]
This was more reasonable than the old witch's earlier position, so <FirstName> let it drop.
[Continue.]
<FirstName> went back outside.
[Continue.]
"And your errand?"
"I found the hunter and slew him, as you asked. Here's his blood."
"I have more blood."
<FirstName> admitted that <he/she> had brought them no blood.
"You told me to look for the hunter who shoots with arrows like this. But all three of them use arrows like this."

"I may have overstated the arrow's conclusiveness. But it is still useful. You know that Nnenne's killer is one of the three who shoots with such arrows. Better to know that the killer is one of three than it is to guess that he's one of three thousand."
"Ah. You must be a hungry witch. Well, sit down. Middle One has made some food for you."
<FirstName> complied.

Middle One put down a loaf of hard, black bread, some cheese, and a cup of tea. It had a piney taste, and <FirstName> wondered if it was, in fact, made from pine needles. The bread seemed almost too hard to eat, but <FirstName> was surprised to discover that it was savory, just a little sour, and very filling. It went well with the cheese.
<FirstName> broke the silence. "I met a spirit in the woods."
The witches looked intently at <FirstName>.
"Does the name Malkin mean anything to you?"
"Malkin was a witch, like you."
[Continue.]
"Before Nnenne there was Malkin," put in Middle One.
"He was the third in your coven?"

"Yes. You know the Laws. Always three. He was our third, before he left, and then Nnenne, and then you -- if, in fact, you ever stop pestering us with questions. He preferred independence to being coven-bound; less power, true, but more freedom."
"What's become of him?"
"Why didn't you mention him before?"
"He agreed to a coven-breaking?"
"Why did the kami bring him up?"
"What's become of him?"
"He's alive, if that's what you mean. We haven't seen him for many seasons."
[Continue.]
"We tend not to visit, and he never does."
[Continue.]
"Just so."
"He was the third in your coven?"
"Why didn't you mention him before?"
"Why did the kami bring him up?"
"He agreed to a coven-breaking?"
"Why didn't you mention him before?"
'Why would we? Malkin didn't kill Nnenne, of that you can be sure. Avenging our sister is what matters to us."
"So he was the third in your coven?"

"Yes. You know the Laws. Always three. He was our third, before he left, and then Nnenne, and then you -- if, in fact, you ever stop pestering us with questions. He preferred independence to being coven-bound; less power, true, but more freedom."
"And what is he doing now?"
"He's alive, if that's what you mean. We haven't seen him for many seasons."
"He agreed to a coven-breaking?"
"Why did the kami bring him up?"
"Why did the kami bring him up?"

"The kami have lived in these woods longer than we have. They know everything that happens here, the secrets of root and stone, tooth and claw. Our secrets, too. They dislike us, and they look on us the way an old king might look at an upstart lord."
[Continue.]

"I suppose they've taken an interest in you because you mean to join us." Eldest Lady sniffed. "My guess? They told you about him because they wanted to sow mistrust between you and us. But Malkin's story has little to do with you."
[Continue.]
"Nothing and everything."
[Continue.]

"Just so: you wouldn't be here if Malkin hadn't left, but beyond that he's unimportant. As for the kami -- they traffic in secrets. They will try to win you over with trivial ones and betray you and yours when it suits them. Don't let them."
"Can you tell me more about him? I'm curious."
"No. The subject doesn't appeal to me at all."
<FirstName> was unsatisfied but didn't press Eldest Lady any further.
<FirstName> was unsatisfied but didn't press Eldest Lady any further.
"I hope your colloquy with the kami didn't distract you from your purpose. What of your little errand?"
"I found the hunter and slew him, as you asked. Here's his blood."
"I have more blood."
"The goose-fletched arrows," said <FirstName>. "I found out a boy makes them."
<FirstName> admitted that <he/she> had brought them no blood.
"I thought not. Tomorrow, then? The day after? Don't let too many tomorrows pass. Remember: we must have it by noon on the eleventh."
[Continue.]

Afterwards, Middle One showed the young witch to <his/her> bed. It was a hard, narrow thing with a thin blanket of wool on top of it, a wooden pillow, and a threadbare gray sheet. It sat beneath an open window that looked south into the woods.
"This will do. Thank you, Middle One."
<He/She> lay down and soon fell asleep. Knott, meanwhile, changed back into a normal gourd, and Pharaoh perched on the windowsill all night, his head tucked into one wing.
"This doesn't look very comfortable."
"Comfort is a rotten egg. The bed will serve."
[Continue.]
<He/She> lay down and soon fell asleep. Knott, meanwhile, changed back into a normal gourd, and Pharaoh perched on the windowsill all night, his head tucked into one wing.
[Continue.]
In the morning, Middle One gave <FirstName> a tin cup of chicory root tea and another chunk of the black bread they'd had for dinner.
[Continue.]

"Be careful," said Eldest Lady as <FirstName> was leaving. "There is treachery in the air. Don't breathe too deep."

The young witch noticed that she looked drained and even more haggard than usual.
[End.]
[Continue.]
The events of the last two days had taxed the young witch, and <he/she> fell asleep on the hard, small bed as if it had light sheets and soft cushions.
[End.]
[Continue.]
Though the night was almost as warm as the day had been, the song of the crickets and a light breeze that blew through the window put the young witch to sleep within minutes.
[End.]
[Continue.]
The young witch could not get to sleep for some time that night, maybe because of the unusually rich supper <he/she>'d had -- and as soon as <he/she> did, a thunderstorm woke <him/her> up.
[Continue.]

<He/She> fell back asleep, or thought <he/she> did. If <he/she> did, the storm continued in <his/her> dreams, the thunder becoming an alien voice that warned <him/her> against unknown trespasses <he/she> was on the verge of committing, the wind in the trees becoming the marching of an army sent to seize <him/her>.
[Continue.]

The next morning, <FirstName> woke to an empty house. Where had the witches gone? But then Middle One came in from the back yard with a basket full of tomatoes. Eldest Lady was on another errand, the witch explained.
[Continue.]
"But she'll be back any moment. She is very busy these days with leavings and comings. Shoo now. Take this tomato -- we have too many."
[End.]
[Continue.]

It was August, but the day had been mild and breezy. When night fell, it became almost cold. When the young witch woke the next morning, <he/she> was surprised to find Middle One's white fawn pressed up against <his/her> legs. As soon as <he/she> stirred, the creature darted off.
[Continue.]
Middle One gave <FirstName> some especially dark chicory root tea. Eldest Lady said nothing to <him/her>.
<FirstName> was grateful. <He/She> didn't need any urgent reminders that today was <his/her> last full day.
<FirstName> opened the door and went out.
[End.]
"Don't doubt me," <he/she> said to Eldest Lady. "I won't fail the coven."
Eldest Lady merely nodded.
[Continue.]
<FirstName> opened the door and went out.
[Continue.]
<FirstName> went back outside.
[End.]

actions.a_parameter_1:
NEW JOURNAL ENTRY!
According to Eldest Lady, Malkin had been part of the coven before Nnenne. It was unclear why the kami brought him up. Perhaps another spirit would be willing to tell the young witch more.

subNodes.conversationText: "He agreed to a coven-breaking?"
"He left, didn't he?"
[Continue.]
Middle One smiled kindly at <FirstName>.
"What's become of him?"
"Why didn't you mention him before?"
"Why did the kami bring him up?"
"The spirit told me to mention someone named Malkin. I saw him in a vision."
"Malkin was a witch, like you."
"Who is Malkin, and what are you hiding?"
"Malkin was a witch, like you."
After their meal, <FirstName> announced that <he/she> had the hunter's blood.
"Let's see it," said Eldest Lady.
Their meal over, <FirstName> drew out the second hunter's blood. "I have more."
"Do you indeed? And is it guilty blood this time?"
Now done eating, <FirstName> brought up <his/her> most recent conversation with the spirits.
Eldest Lady sighed. "I've already told you: stay away from them. They will distract you, as they did him."
"I know what happened to Malkin. You tricked him, and the kami transformed him into a tree," said <FirstName> suddenly.
"So. They showed you."
[Continue.]
"Sometimes, I wish I was a tree. Birds in my hair, feet in the cool soil, no scolding..."
[Continue.]
"Quiet, Middle One."
[Continue.]
"Well, now you know Malkin's secret. And what does it matter? You've pried into mysteries that have nothing to do with your task. Nnenne is still unavenged."
"What about Malkin? He was wronged, too."
"The kami didn't show you everything. He was far from harmless."
"You broke the Laws. 'Do no harm to anyone in the coven,' they say."
"You've given me no reason to believe anything you say."

It was audacious for a witch to challenge the elders of a coven she wasn't yet bound to in this way. Middle One turned away, fearing the coming storm. But Eldest Lady only shrugged.

"Disbelieve me if you like. I speak the truth."
[Continue.]
"I broke none of the Laws by telling Malkin what I told him. I did him no harm. The spirits did the harm, and no Laws bind them." There was bitterness in her voice.
"But you knew something bad would happen to him."
"He stole your grimoire. What apprentice hasn't coveted their master's books?"
"If that was all..."
[Continue.]

"I guessed but did not foresee what would happen when he spoke to the kami. I’ll not deny that I meddled, that I went to the kami myself about him. But in all this I obeyed the Laws. He was bad, . His appetite and his power. He was not harmless. The binding of the coven chafed. The Laws chafed. He thought only of himself. What I could foresee – far more certainly than what happened to him -- was his life as it would have otherwise been. A torment for others, a danger to us.”
"How did you know that? We do not prophesy."
Middle One squinted at Eldest Lady.
[Continue.]
"The kami showed me, of course."
"You tell me not to trust them, but you trusted them yourself?"
Eldest Lady drew herself up, finally really angry. She seemed hideously tall in the small cabin. Thunder rumbled outside. Middle One cowered and crawled under the table.
[Continue.]

"I have been patient with you, but you go too far. I am an Elder Witch. I have walked the Roots of the World. I've beheld the Strangling Twins and the Bound Ones with my own eyes. I can stand before the kami as their equal, and I can distinguish their truths from their falsehoods. I scorn your questions."
[Continue.]
The storm passed. Middle One crawled out from under the table.
[Continue.]

"The kami have sown this mistrust between us on purpose. Your task was to find Nnenne's killer before the coven-binding. They've led you astray into this tedious maze, and now your time is almost up. If you fail, another year passes without a coven to protect us from the ravages of old age. And you, too, will suffer. You'll have to find another coven to join, and it will be difficult. The witch who disappoints Eldest Lady will not make friends easily."
"Don't worry. I'll bring back the blood of Nnenne's killer."
<FirstName> left the house. As <he/she> paused outside, wondering what to do next, <he/she> felt the familiar disorientation of being in the presence of the kami.
[Continue.]
"Seek the Congress of Moths."
[Continue.]

"Find their hidden
Door."
[Continue.]
"It opens in the western woods."
[Continue.]
"They know who killed your witch."
[End.]

actions.a_parameter_1:
NEW JOURNAL ENTRY!
Eldest Lady revealed that her own knowledge about Malkin's supposed evil came from her discussions with the kami. When the young witch challenged Eldest Lady about this, part of Eldest Lady's true power was revealed. She insisted she was the equal of the kami and could not be tricked by them.

NEW JOURNAL ENTRY!
After confronting Eldest Lady about Malkin's transformation into a tree, the young witch was told that this knowledge changed nothing and that the kami were trying to sow distrust between them. Nnenne still needed to be avenged for the coven-binding to happen. Soon after, the young witch had a vision of the kami. They said: "Seek the Congress of Moths. Find their hidden door. It opens in the western woods. They know who killed your witch."

subNodes.conversationText: The young witch's silence indicated that <he/she> understood.
<FirstName> left the house. As <he/she> paused outside, wondering what to do next, <he/she> felt the familiar disorientation of being in the presence of the kami.
"You make threats."
"I have no choice. Kindly directions haven't worked."
"Don't worry. I'll bring back the blood of Nnenne's killer."
The young witch's silence indicated that <he/she> understood.
[Continue.]

"The kami have sown this mistrust between us on purpose. Your task was to find Nnenne's killer before the coven-binding. They've led you astray, and now your time is almost up. If you fail, another year passes without a coven to protect us from the ravages of old age. And you, too, will suffer. You'll have to find another coven to join, and it will be difficult. The witch who disappoints Eldest Lady will not make friends easily."
"Don't worry. I'll bring back the blood of Nnenne's killer."

The witches went to bed. As <FirstName> lay there in the dark, staring up through the window at the black night sky and the glowing stars -- they had never seemed so close, <he/she> mused -- <he/she> heard voices as clearly as if the speakers were in the room.
[Continue.]
"Seek the Congress of Moths."
[Continue.]

"Find their hidden
Door."
[Continue.]
"It opens in the western woods."
[Continue.]
"They know who killed your witch."
[Continue.]
The voices of the kami rang through <his/her> dreams that night, but what else they said and what the dreams were about were forgotten when the sun rose.
[End.]

NEW JOURNAL ENTRY!
After confronting Eldest Lady about Malkin's transformation into a tree, the young witch was told that this knowledge changed nothing and that the kami were trying to sow distrust between them. Nnenne still needed to be avenged for the coven-binding to happen. Soon after, the young witch had a vision of the kami. They said: "Seek the Congress of Moths. Find their hidden door. It opens in the western woods. They know who killed your witch."

NEW JOURNAL ENTRY!
Eldest Lady revealed that her own knowledge about Malkin's supposed evil came from her discussions with the kami. When the young witch challenged Eldest Lady about this, part of Eldest Lady's true power was revealed. She insisted she was the equal of the kami and could not be tricked by them.

subNodes.conversationText: The young witch's silence indicated that <he/she> understood.

The witches went to bed. As <FirstName> lay there in the dark, staring up through the window at the black night sky and the glowing stars -- they had never seemed so close, <he/she> mused -- <he/she> heard voices as clearly as if the speakers were in the room.
"You make threats."
"I have no choice. Kindly directions haven't worked."
"Don't worry. I'll bring back the blood of Nnenne's killer."
"I've seen into his mind. I've seen nothing worse there than normal human weakness."
"You saw the parts of his mind the kami wanted you to see."
"And how did you come to know his mind so well?"
Middle One squinted at Eldest Lady.
"I have seen into his mind. It was all too human."
"You saw the parts of his mind the kami wanted you to see."
"You broke the Laws. 'Do no harm to anyone in the coven,' they say."
"The Laws! Did you really, sister?" cried Middle One, though she knew all the particulars.
[Continue.]
"I broke none of the Laws by telling Malkin what I told him. I did him no harm. The spirits did the harm, and no Laws bind them." There was bitterness in her voice.
"But you knew something bad would happen to him."

"I guessed but did not foresee what would happen when he spoke to the kami. I’ll not deny that I meddled, that I went to the kami myself about him. But in all this I obeyed the Laws. He was bad, . His appetite and his power. He was not harmless. The binding of the coven chafed. The Laws chafed. He thought only of himself. What I could foresee – far more certainly than what happened to him -- was his life as it would have otherwise been. A torment for others, a danger to us.”
"He stole your grimoire. What apprentice hasn't coveted their master's books?"
"I still mean to avenge her, but Malkin's fate makes me uneasy."
"The kami didn't show you everything. He was far from harmless."
Then <FirstName> broke the news: the Congress had shown <him/her> how Nnenne was killed.
They sat in silence for the remainder of the meal.
It grew late.

"Your second day has come and gone. I hope you were not as idle as Middle One."
[Continue.]
"Idle hands make no dinner, but dinner these hands made," Middle One remonstrated.
[Continue.]
"Mushrooms, butcher's nuts, and sorrel leaves!" Eldest Lady cackled. "You set a basket in the woods and brought back only what fell into it."
[Continue.]
"Not true," said Middle One, "for I didn't fall into my own basket, yet here I am."
<FirstName> sat down to eat.

Eldest Lady had been right about the sorrel leaves. But in addition to the sweet butcher's nuts and earthy mushroom heads were many berries, seeds, and herbs, and a cold, peppery sauce that made the flavors work well together. The older witch's description had been quite unfair.
<FirstName> broke the silence. "I met a spirit in the woods."
After their meal, <FirstName> announced that <he/she> had the hunter's blood.
Their meal over, <FirstName> drew out the second hunter's blood. "I have more."
Now done eating, <FirstName> brought up <his/her> most recent conversation with the spirits.
"I know what happened to Malkin. You tricked him, and the kami transformed him into a tree," said <FirstName> suddenly.
UNUSED They sat in silence for the remainder of the meal.
Then <FirstName> broke the news: the Congress had shown <him/her> how Nnenne was killed.
"The goose-fletched arrows," said <FirstName>. "I found out a boy makes them."
They sat in silence for the remainder of the meal.
"<He/She>'s back, Middle One. Put out the dinner things."
[Continue.]

First, Middle One set out a pitcher of water and some cups. The pitcher was the same one <FirstName> had used when planting the seed that transformed into Knott. It was odd to see it performing this quotidian service.

After that, Middle One set down plates with mounds of an oily, dark mush on them. <FirstName> wasn't sure what it was, but <he/she> thought <he/she> saw berries in it.
<He/She> poked at it with <his/her> fork.
"Less brave than a bird, are we? Sister, <he/she>'s poking at <his/her> food."
[Continue.]
"Is <he/she>? If <he/she>'s not careful, it might poke back."
[Continue.]
"Nonsense! It is neither crab nor cane nor conscience."
[Continue.]
"It is too hot to cook," explained Eldest Lady, "and Middle One has many jars of this stuff -- tallow and berries and meat. Good for the winter, good for the summer. Eat it."
[Continue.]

The young witch obeyed. It was salty, a little tart, and had surprisingly sweet bits -- not just the berries, but meat that had been well marinated before drying. The water from the pitcher helped it go down. The meal was unprepossessing but delicious.
[Continue.]
<He/She> tasted it.

Middle One glanced at <FirstName>'s drained cup and refilled it. <FirstName> had been thirstier than <he/she> realized. The water cooled and fortified <him/her>. The older witch seemed pleased.
<FirstName> broke the silence. "I met a spirit in the woods."

Middle One was alone, sitting at the kitchen table, slicing onions.
[Continue.]
"Eldest Lady had an errand in Banli Village," said the witch, studying the onions while cutting them. "She'll be back soon -- after the hog whose bristles she means to blanch turns white."
"Sounds like a serious errand," said <FirstName> dryly.
"All errands are frivolous. All sport is serious."
[Continue.]
"Blanching hogs? Why would a witch of Eldest Lady's power do that?"
"All errands are frivolous. All sport is serious."
"I see."
"No, you don't."
[Continue.]
Middle One threw the onions in a skillet with sage and mushrooms. Eldest Lady strode in some time later, after night had fallen.
[Continue.]
"The tables have turned, and you had to wait for me for once," she said to . She looked very weary, as if she'd made a long journey. Her appearance belied her taunt.
"And how is the hog at Banli Village?"
Eldest Lady looked inquisitively at Middle One before responding. "It squeals too much."
[Continue.]

Middle One put down plates of beef and cups of wine -- the first <FirstName> had had in company with the witches. The meat was tender and good, the sage sharpening its savoriness, a mint salad complementing it. The wine was bitter but pleasant and earthy.
<FirstName> broke the silence. "I met a spirit in the woods."

Middle One put down plates of beef and cups of wine -- the first <FirstName> had had in company with the witches. The meat was tender and good, the sage sharpening its savoriness, a mint salad complementing it. The wine was bitter but pleasant and earthy.

<FirstName> had not seen the witches' familiars very often. Eldest Lady had a big gray cat named Gus who, according to Eldest Lady, spent most of his time hunting birds in the meadows. Middle One had a three-legged white fawn who never aged -- according to Middle One. Whenever the young witch came into the room, it clattered to the older witch's bed and curled up underneath it.

Tonight, though, both animals were in the kitchen. Middle One was cooking, and once in a while she'd drop a little alfalfa for the deer and bits of trout for the cat.
[Continue.]
"The animals, at least, enjoy Middle One's cooking."
"I enjoy it too," said <FirstName> honestly. It had consistently surprised <him/her>.
"I find it -- tolerable."
[Continue.]
"I find you -- intolerable!" said Middle One with what seemed like real anger -- the first had ever seen from them.
[Continue.]
"Good. Then I shan't be eaten."
[Continue.]

Middle One giggled, the anger -- if anger it had really been -- passing as suddenly as it had come. The gray cat tired of waiting for more fish and began chasing one of the crickets that always found their way in from the meadow.
[Continue.]
"Your Gus loves to hunt singing things, crickets and finches," observed Middle One. "There were two finches dead at the door this morning, one purple, one yellow."
[Continue.]
"He and I share an aversion to idle noise. And you, young witch? Do you make music?"
"I sing and can play an instrument, but not very well," said <FirstName> humbly.
"I do not believe you -- I'm sure you can play marvelously. Less music, more hunting from now on."
[Continue.]
"You do know that tomorrow is the last full day you have to find that blood...?"
[Continue.]

Middle One began singing:

"A finch is a hunter of aphids,
A cat is a hunter of finches.
The young witch? <He/She> hunts hunters
Standing taller by some inches."
[Continue.]
The cat sauntered out of the room.
[Continue.]
"Gus tires of Middle One's noise and is free to leave. I tire of it and have nowhere to go."
[Continue.]
Middle One served dinner -- thin pancakes of shredded potatoes, carrots, trout, and alfalfa, rather salty but golden brown and crunchy. There was a tart sauce to dip them in.
[Continue.]
"Ah. Malkin's favorite," said Eldest Lady, looking inquisitively at Middle One. "A curious choice."
<FirstName> broke the silence. "I met a spirit in the woods."

"Come in, come in. It's an important night," said Middle One.
"And I have important news," said <FirstName>.
"Ah! You have finally brought us some blood?"
"No. But I know how Nnenne died."
<FirstName> told them about <his/her> dealings with the Congress of Moths and that they'd shown <him/her> how Nnnenne died.

"You visited the Roots of the World?"
"No -- And I doubt I will ever bring you any."
Eldest Lady frowned but said nothing, inquisitive rather than angry. Middle One's eyes were wide.

<FirstName> told them about <his/her> dealings with the Congress of Moths and that they'd shown <him/her> how Nnnenne died.
"Sit, sit," said Middle One, pulling out <FirstName>'s chair and gesturing to the seat. A savory pie steamed on the table. The house smelled of onion, garlic, and cooked meat.
[Continue.]

Eldest Lady took her own seat. She said no word to <FirstName>. There was no need. Tomorrow would be momentous, one way or another. Everything depended on the young witch, and everyone gathered at the witches' table knew it.
[Continue.]
"Go on, dear," said Middle One, handing <him/her> a knife. "You can have the first slice."
<FirstName> took it and cut the pie.
The moment the blade passed through the crust, blood rose through the crack and began seeping out the edges.
[Continue.]
Middle One shrieked, stood up, and backed away into the wall.
[Continue.]
"Middle One! What is this?!" demanded Eldest Lady. The blood had filled the dish and was now pouring out onto the table. The young witch and Eldest Lady stood too as it gushed out.
[Continue.]
"I had nothing to do with it!"
[Continue.]
Then Eldest Lady and Middle One froze. They didn't even appear to be breathing. Voices boomed from all around.
[Continue.]
'Tomorrow is the fateful day, young witch."
[Continue.]
"Your course is all but set."
[Continue.]

"The company
You keep -- they cannot force you to their will
Or unspill what they spilled."
[Continue.]
"Find the axe."
[Continue.]
"Find the axe and cut the thing that binds them."
[Continue.]

"Find the axe and fell the tree whose roots
Would drink the huntress's blood."
[Continue.]
"Kill Malkin."
[Continue.]
"Kill him."
[Continue.]
"Kill him."
[Continue.]
The spell that had held Eldest and Middle One broke, and the blood stopped gushing from the meat pie but still dripped onto the floor.
[Continue,]
"The kami," surmised Eldest Lady. She hadn't heard anything. "Middle One, clean up this mess. It's no use eating tonight. <FirstName>, you will have to go to bed hungry."
[Continue.]
"I will see to it that they do not toy with us tomorrow." She strode through the door into the night.
[Continue.]
Middle One looked ready to say something but then thought better of it.
[Continue.]
Soon <FirstName> was in bed.
[Continue.]

The sun rose not long after <he/she> had finally fallen asleep.

The dreaded day had come.
[Continue.]
The witches were nowhere to be seen. <FirstName> left the house.

Then <FirstName> broke the news: the Congress had shown <him/her> how Nnenne was killed.
"You visited the Roots of the World?"
"Yes -- and I learned a great deal."
"Well, I suppose you have more questions for us."
"You didn't tell me that Nnenne was transformed when she was shot."
"The kami aided me."
"Of course they did."
[Continue.]
"Well, I suppose you have more questions for us."
<FirstName> ignored the question. "You deceived me again."
"How so?"
"You didn't tell me that Nnenne was transformed when she was shot."
"What does that matter? The arrow still killed her."
"Yes, but the hunter was innocent and only meant to shoot a deer. I've been looking for a murderer."

"Innocence and guilt mean nothing. A witch should disavow those things for herself and disbelieve then in others. I certainly do."

"If I am guilty, I am as guilty as a briar, a spider. or a hawk on high. I hurt, I poison, I kill. I am not boasting, only telling the truth. And yet I could do worse, and I refrain -- not because I fear any law, or shame, or the stigma of guilt, but because my desires govern themselves."
"Not only have I killed two innocents, but I did so for no reason whatsoever."
"An innocent killing," said Middle One sadly.
[Continue.]

"Innocence and guilt mean nothing. A witch should disavow those things for herself and disbelieve then in others. I certainly do."

[Continue.]
Middle One began walking around the kitchen, opening and closing cupboards.
"I'm glad states don't govern themselves the way you do."
"Don't they? You are naive, <FirstName>. You will know better when you join the coven."
[Continue.]

The old witch changed the subject.

"What else did the Congress show you?"
"I saw into Nnenne's mind. She referred to Malkin as if he was part of the coven."
"You said Nnenne was picking juneberries to make you tarts. That was a lie."
The young witch was done asking questions. <He/She> had too much to think about.
"An admirable perspective," said <FirstName>.
"How nice that there's such accord between us."
[Continue.]
<FirstName> found much to fault in this philosophy, but <he/she> said nothing.

"Malkin was still bound to the coven when the kami transformed him. He never left."
"But he's a tree."
"He is no ordinary tree. A part of him is still embedded within it -- only a  part, and not the best part."
[Continue.]
"I never got to see the best part," said Middle One wistfully.
"But the Laws... A coven cannot have more than three. How did Nnenne join the coven? How would I?"
"The witches' number must always be three. It remains true. Malkin, though still bound to the coven, is not truly a witch anymore and does not count as one for the sake of that Law."
"Why haven't you destroyed him?"
"Malkin had some influence over Nnenne. I do not want to find myself in the same position."
"Enough about Malkin. I have more to ask you about Nnenne."
The young witch was done asking questions. <He/She> had too much to think about.
"Why haven't you destroyed him?"

"Why would I? He is harmless now. Even if I wanted to, the Laws keep me from doing him harm. And he cannot simply be cut down or set on fire like a normal tree. He is the kami's creature, and they protect him for their own inscrutable purposes."

"Nnenne had her own troubles," said Eldest Lady. "Troubles with men. Troubles that had nothing to do with Malkin. It is true that we are always aware of him -- just as we are aware of each other. But that is how all covens work. Nnenne's unhappiness was my own fault. When we bound her, she didn't know about Malkin."
"If the kami hadn't told me, I wouldn't know about him either."
"I would have told you before the binding. Indeed, there's more to tell you I won't disclose now. I will tell you at the binding. Then the time will be ripe."
